3. In the ðš–ðšðšŒðšŠðš›ðšœ data set, fit a linear regression model of weight (predictor) on mpg (outcome). Get a 95% **confidence** interval for the expected mpg at the average weight. What is the lower endpoint?

```r
> rm1 <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data=mtcars)

> (summary(rm1)$coeff)
             Estimate Std. Error   t value     Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept) 37.285126   1.877627 19.857575 8.241799e-19
wt          -5.344472   0.559101 -9.559044 1.293959e-10

> ndata1 <- data.frame(wt=mean(mtcars$wt))

> predict(rm1, ndata1, interval=("confidence"))
       fit      lwr      upr
1 20.09062 18.99098 21.19027
```

OR.....

```r
data(mtcars)
> rm1  <- lm(mpg ~ I(wt - mean(wt)), data = mtcars)
> confint(rm1)
                     2.5 %    97.5 %
(Intercept)      18.990982 21.190268
I(wt - mean(wt)) -6.486308 -4.202635
```

OR..... 

```r
> sumCoef <- summary(rm1)$coeff

> sumCoef[1,1] + c(-1, 1) * qt(.975, df = rm1$df) * sumCoef[1, 2]
[1] 18.99098 21.19027

```

6. Consider again the ðš–ðšðšŒðšŠðš›ðšœ data set and a linear regression model with mpg as predicted by weight (in 1,000 lbs). A â€œshortâ€ ton is defined as 2,000 lbs. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the expected change in mpg per 1 short ton increase in weight. Give the lower endpoint.

```r

> coef <- summary(rm1)$coeff
```

8. 
I have an outcome, Y, and a predictor, X and fit a linear regression model with Y=Î²0+Î²1X+Ïµ to obtain Î²^0 and Î²^1. What would be the consequence to the subsequent slope and intercept if I were to refit the model with a new regressor, X+c for some constant, c?

This is exactly covered in the notes. But note that if Y=Î²0+Î²1X+Ïµ then Y=Î²0âˆ’cÎ²1+Î²1(X+c)+Ïµ so that the answer is that the intercept gets subtracted by cÎ²1

```r
c<-5
cf1<-summary(fit)$coefficients
cf1

fit4<-lm(y~I(x+c)) # add some constant c
cf2<-summary(fit4)$coefficients
cf2

b0<-cf1[1,1]
b1<-cf1[2,1]
c(b0,b1)

b0 - c*b1

```

9. 
Refer back to the mtcars data set with mpg as an outcome and weight (wt) as the predictor. About what is the ratio of the the sum of the squared errors, âˆ‘ni=1(Yiâˆ’Y^i)2 when comparing a model with just an intercept (denominator) to the model with the intercept and slope (numerator)?

Yi^=YÂ¯Yi^=YÂ¯  when the fitted model has an intercept only.

```r
fit_num <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data=mtcars)
fit_denom <- lm(mpg ~ 1 + offset(0 * wt), data=mtcars)
sum(resid(fit_num)^2) / sum(resid(fit_denom)^2)
```

or 

```r
fit5<-lm(y ~ 1) #only intercept
fit6<-lm(y ~ x - 1) #only slope
plot(x,y)

abline(fit,col="red")
abline(fit5,col="blue")
abline(fit6,col="green")
```

OR ....

```r
fit1 <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars)
fit2 <- lm(mpg ~ 1, data = mtcars)
1 - summary(fit1)$r.squared

sse1 <- sum((predict(fit1) - mtcars$mpg)^2)
sse2 <- sum((predict(fit2) - mtcars$mpg)^2)
sse1/sse2

```
